review_title: Values and Mission Driven School with Many Opportunities
pros:
Guided by values and mission of social and environmental justice (not always actualized perfectly but continual conversation and efforts to get closer to ideal)

Great community. Smart, passionate, engaged students.

Freedom to experiment/innovate with teaching, and to teach things that matter in ways that matter.

Opportunities and support to create new things and to get involved in leadership, etc.

Prescott and surrounding areas are beautiful, lots of outdoor/nature activities, and weather is amazing.
cons:
Small school with a very different vibe (and different types of opportunities) than a large research university. This can be a pro or a con depending on what you're looking for. 

Not necessarily a con, but it definitely has that passionate non-profit thing going (people often put in more than full-time hours and the pay is modest, but meaning and fulfillment are plentiful if that's what you're looking for).

Prescott could be cooler culturally, but Flagstaff, Sedona, and Phoenix are all fairly accessible.

pros: Nothing in particular comes to mind.
cons: The people in this department are terrible human beings.

review_title: If you are looking for a raise, look elsewhere...
pros:
People are usually very nice 
Fun opportunities such as orientation and possible travel
great location
values would be ideal if they actually lived them
cons:
Systems are very unorganized
Working with Heidi Robbe was miserable and she is not open to any feedback
You will acquire the work of at least 3 people while you are there
Raises are nonexistent
bonuses? never heard of them.
Not a diverse environment

review_title: The students are the best part
pros: The students are great. Some of the classes are really interesting.

job_title: Early Childhood Teacher in Cottonwood, AZ
pros: Mostly online degrees, which means you can attend from anywhere.
cons: Online degrees, which limits your access to other students and teachers.

pros: Holidays, an academic e-mail address also comes in handy.
cons: They claim to teach environmental sustainability and social justice, and that their pedagogy includes experiential education and self-directed learning. In reality, it’s all a collection of fad-driven culture meant to enhance their identity so that they can rip-off trust-fund babies. Since 2014, they’ve began focusing on their social justice identity bragging how they’ve employed discrimination in hiring to populate their leadership with 75% women, and a handful of transgendered and people of color. So, they prefer to hire non-white, non-Judeo-Christian, non-heterosexual, non-male, non-conservatives. Good for them, but they only do it to check boxes. Once hired, these people are tokens that are marginalized back into their stereotypical roles, such as women being nothing more than secretaries with “Director” in their job titles. Since doing that, their gross revenue has dropped more than 35% and their gross employee pay more than 40%, while preserving their execute pay; information is public and available on their IRS form 990’s. Year over year decline in revenue, pay, enrollment, and retention. And in my day-to-day, this fake identity was an everyday problem that interfered with every business decision, every task, every milestone, and every event. Trying to reason with the senior leadership meant facing fanatical opposition, and it usually ends in termination.

review_title: Non-profit means low pay but lots of fun
pros: Community oriented and full of passion. There are many things that keep a college up and running and one key factor is passionate individuals. If you truly want to make a difference in the world, this college campus is one place where you can feel fulfilled.
cons: Low wages or low hours were the drawback to this position I accepted. Non-profit colleges are hard to make a decent living but what is more important to the individual? To be rich and unfulfilled? Or does one rather being wealthy? Needs can be met with the salaries and wages here, but one would also feel fulfilled at the end of the day.

pros: Well, there are some good things, but none of them are really notable. I suppose doing nothing and getting paid for it is something. I don't do anything meaningful here.
cons: First they came for the accountants and I did not speak out because I was not in accounting. Then they came for the facilities workers and I did not speak out because I was not in facilities. Then they came for the marketing workers and I did not speak out because I was not in marketing. Then they came for the managers and I did not speak out because I was not in management. Then they came for me and there was no one left to speak out for me.

review_title: Great place to work in Prescott, Arizona.
job_title: Field Operations Assistant in Prescott, AZ
pros: Great bunch of intelligent people, casual college environment.  I worked in a variety of departments in various roles and worked with amazing people that will remain friends with. I had a great boss!
cons: Wages are low. The medical benefits are just average and I would have like to see better rates and co payments for the employee.

pros: Only the people, and then only some of the people.  They do have a lot of days off and vacation time.  They're pretty good about flex time.
cons:
They use fear based management to drive their employees.  They pretend to be diverse and inclusive, but it's really just for show.  There's high turnover. 
 They have been financially unstable for many years.

pros: A lot of freedom in teaching classes and the students are motivated.
cons: The corporate atmosphere has changed the environment at the college. It's being run like a business now due to financial problems in the past.

review_title: Great College to attend or work at!
pros: Mission, Community, Wonderful students, staff and faculty
cons: Not well enough known for the excellent education offered so not enough students apply
Weak leadership, low pay. A once great culture is declining.

pros: Excellent in house supervisor. Outstanding flexibility. Family atmosphere.
cons: Siloing. Poor advancement opportunity. Poor benefits.
